'''James Michael Johnson''' (born January 30, 1972) is an American attorney, politician, and former talk radio host serving as the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. representative]] for [[Louisiana's 4th congressional district]]. First elected in 2016, he is the vice chair of the [[House Republican Conference]]. He previously chaired the House [[Republican Study Committee]], the largest caucus of conservatives in Congress, and a coalition of socially and fiscally conservative members of the larger [[House Republican Conference]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thenewsstar.com/story/news/2018/11/16/breaking-congressman-mike-johnson-wins-post-gop-launching-pad/2023910002/|title=Mike Johnson wins post on GOP launching pad|first=Greg|last=Hilburn|newspaper=[[The News-Star|The Monroe News-Star]]|date=November 16, 2018|access-date=November 18, 2018}}</ref>

From 2015 to 2017, Johnson served as a representative in the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] for the 8th district in [[Bossier Parish, Louisiana|Bossier Parish]].

==Early life and education==
Johnson was born in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legaldirectories.com/Johnson-J-Michael-838210-Atty.aspx|title=J. Michael Johnson - Lawyer in Bossier City, Louisiana (LA) Bossier County - legaldirectories.com|website=legaldirectories.com}}</ref> the oldest of four children of Jeanne Johnson and James Patrick Johnson, a firefighter who founded the [[nonprofit organization]] the Percy R. Johnson Burn Foundation, named after his partner Percy R. Johnson, the city's first African-American fire instructor and captain, who died in the line of duty.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://percyrjohnson.org/percy.html|title=About Percy R. Johnson}}</ref> Johnson was also critically burned and disabled in the line of duty during the fire. Johnson has two brothers, Chris and Josh, and a sister, Laura.<ref name="fathersobit">{{cite news|url= http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/shreveporttimes/obituary.aspx?pid=183039473#sthash.Bgl9ucQ8.dpuf|title=James Patrick Johnson|newspaper=[[The Times (Shreveport)|The Shreveport Times]]|access-date=December 13, 2016}}</ref>

In high school, Johnson was a member of Louisiana Boys State. He graduated from [[Captain Shreve High School]] in Shreveport. He received an undergraduate degree in [[business administration]] from [[Louisiana State University]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]]. He holds a [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Louisiana State University Law Center]],<ref name="bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.mikejohnsonlouisiana.com/#!portfolio/cee5|title=About Mike |publisher=mikejohnsonlouisiana.com|access-date=March 30, 2015}}</ref> and worked as [[Lawyer|constitutional attorney]] in [[Benton, Louisiana]].

==Legal career==
Before his election to Congress, Johnson was a partner in the Kitchens Law Firm and a senior attorney and national media spokesman for the [[Alliance Defense Fund]], now known as [[Alliance Defending Freedom]].<ref name=mjohnson>{{cite web|url=http://www.arklatexhomepage.com/story/d/story/conservative-republican-walks-into-louisiana-legis/29275/stOTzOyAiU6l-uIul9MOdw|title=Conservative Republican walks into Louisiana Legislature's District 8 seat unopposed|date=January 10, 2015|first=Nancy|last=Cook|publisher=[[KTAL-TV]] ([[NBC]]): arklatexhomepage.com|access-date=March 30, 2015}}</ref>

Johnson was also formerly chief counsel of the nonprofit law firm Freedom Guard.<ref name=stimes>{{cite news|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/local/2015/01/13/looming-session-leave-little-wiggle-room-johnson/21695793/|title=Looming session leaves little wiggle room for Johnson|first=Alexandria|last=Burris|date=January 16, 2015|newspaper=The Shreveport Times|access-date=March 30, 2015}}</ref>

Johnson served as a trustee of the [[Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission|Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission]] within the [[Southern Baptist Convention]] from 2004 to 2012.

==Louisiana House of Representatives==
===Louisiana Marriage and Conscience Act===
In April 2015, Johnson proposed the Marriage and Conscience Act, a bill similar in content to [[Indiana]]'s controversial [[Religious Freedom Restoration Act (Indiana)|Religious Freedom Restoration Act]] passed a few days earlier, though Johnson denied that his legislation was based on the Indiana law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenewsstar.com/story/news/local/2015/04/01/bossier-legislator-mulls-religious-freedom-bill/70801560/|title=Bossier legislator mulls religious freedom bill|first=Maya|last=Lau|publisher=The Shreveport Times in [[The News-Star|The Monroe News-Star]]|date=April 1, 2015|access-date=April 2, 2015}}</ref>

Johnson's Marriage and Conscience Act would have eliminated Louisiana's ability to withhold a "state license, certification, accreditation, employment, state contracts, state benefits, or tax deductions" from a person or entity based on their views on the institution of marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://710keel.com/rep-mike-johnson-calls-his-marriage-and-conscience-act-a-call-for-freedom-and-tolerance/?trackback=tsmclip|title=Rep. Mike Johnson Calls His Marriage and Conscience Act A Call For "Freedom and Tolerance"|publisher=[[KEEL (AM)]]|access-date=April 7, 2015}}</ref> Critics denounced the bill as an attempt to protect people who discriminate against same-sex married couples.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/05/bobby-jindal-hb-707-and-the-2016-presidential-race/393833/|title=What Will Bobby Jindal's 'Marriage and Conscience Order' Actually Do?|last=Epps|first=Garrett|newspaper=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-02-19|language=en-US}}</ref>

Then-[[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[Bobby Jindal]] pledged to sign Johnson's bill into law if it passed both houses of the legislature.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://theadvocate.com/features/realestate/12184896-70/bobby-jindal-im-holding-firm|title=Bobby Jindal gives his take on gay marriage in New York Times editorial|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=April 23, 2015}}</ref> [[IBM]] and other employers in the region expressed their opposition to the bill, including concerns about the hiring difficulties it would likely produce.<ref name=":0" /> Other politicians also objected, including Baton Rouge Metro Councilman John Delgado, who described Johnson as a "despicable bigot of the highest order" for proposing the bill.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/news/baton-rouge/index.ssf/2015/04/louisiana_religious_freedom_ib.html|title=Louisiana religious freedom bill author a 'despicable bigot,' Baton Rouge council member says|newspaper=NOLA.com|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en-US}}</ref>

On May 19, 2015, the House Civil Law and Procedure Committee voted 10–2 to table the bill, effectively ending its chances to become law.<ref name="billtabled">{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2015/05/louisianas_religious_freedom_b.html|title=Louisiana's religious freedom bill effectively defeated in committee|first=Emily|last=Lane|date=May 19, 2015|newspaper=[[New Orleans Times-Picayune]]|access-date=May 19, 2015}}</ref> Both Republicans and Democrats voted against the bill; other than Johnson, only Republican [[Ray Garofalo]] voted for it.<ref name="billtabled" /> After the bill was tabled, Jindal said that he would issue an [[executive order]] to enforce its intent.<ref name="executiveorder">{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2015/05/bobby_jindal_executive_order_r.html#incart_m-rpt-2|title=Bobby Jindal plans to issue an executive order enforcing intent of religious freedom bill|newspaper=New Orleans Times-Picayune|first=Emily|last=Lane|date=May 19, 2015|access-date=May 19, 2015}}</ref> Johnson planned to reintroduce his own bill in 2016.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence}}

===Other===
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://710keel.com/state-house-of-representatives-vote-to-increase-sales-tax/|title=State House of Representatives Vote to Increase Sales Tax|date=February 25, 2016|publisher=[[KEEL]]|access-date=March 28, 2016}}</ref>

In 2015 and 2016 Johnson led an [[pro-life movement|anti-abortion]] "Life March" in Shreveport-Bossier City.<ref name="congcandidates">{{cite news|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/2016/01/06/4th-district-field-inches-toward-gate/78353064/|title=4th District field inches toward gate|date=January 6, 2016|newspaper=The Shreveport Times|first=Greg|last=Hilburn|access-date=January 7, 2016}}</ref>

Johnson opposed the [[Common Core State Standards Initiative]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehayride.com/2014/12/mike-johnson-grabs-labis-northpac-endorsement/|title=Mike Johnson Grabs LABI's NORTHPAC Endorsement|date=18 December 2014|publisher=thehayride.com|access-date=March 30, 2015}}</ref>

==U.S House of Representatives==
===Elections===

====2016====
On February 10, 2016, Johnson announced his candidacy for the 4th congressional district seat held for eight years by [[John Fleming (American politician)|John Fleming]], who was running for the [[United States Senate]] seat vacated by [[David Vitter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://voterportal.sos.la.gov/Graphical|title=Election Returns|date=December 10, 2016|publisher=Louisiana Secretary of State|access-date=December 13, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kalb.com/home/headlines/State-Rep-Johnson-to-run-for-4th-Congressional-seat-368329101.html|title=State Rep. Johnson to run for 4th Congressional seat|publisher=[[KALB-TV]]|access-date=February 10, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/2016/02/22/shreveport-attorney-rick-john-enters-4th-district-race/80759650/|title=Shreveport attorney enters 4th District race|first=Greg|last=Hilburn|date=February 22, 2016|newspaper=The Shreveport Times|access-date=August 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://voterportal.sos.la.gov/Graphical|title=Election Returns|date=November 8, 2016|publisher=Louisiana Secretary of State|access-date=December 13, 2016}}</ref>

====2018====
In 2018, Johnson won his second term in the U.S. House with 139,307 votes (64%). Democrat Ryan Trundle trailed with 72,923 (34%).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://voterportal.sos.la.gov/Graphical|title=Election Returns|date=November 6, 2018|publisher=Louisiana Secretary of State|access-date=November 8, 2018}}</ref>

====2020====
In 2020, Johnson won his third term in the House with 185,265 votes (60%) to Democratic nominee Kenny Houston's 78,157 (25%).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Mike_Johnson_(Louisiana)|title=Mike Johnson (Louisiana)}}</ref>

===Tenure===
Johnson was sworn into office on January 3, 2017. He is [[Vice Chairman of the United States House of Representatives Republican Conference|Vice Chairman of the Republican Conference]], an Assistant Whip for House Republicans, a member of the Judiciary Committee, the Armed Services Committee, and a member and former Chairman of the [[Republican Study Committee]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Member List|url=https://rsc-walker.house.gov/|publisher=Republican Study Committee|access-date=21 December 2017|archive-date=1 January 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190101195017/https://rsc-walker.house.gov/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

Johnson voted for the [[American Health Care Act of 2017]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2017/roll256.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 256}}</ref>

In December 2017, Johnson voted for the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|Tax Cuts and Jobs Act]].<ref name="Almukhtar">{{cite web|last1=Almukhtar|first1=Sarah|title=How Each House Member Voted on the Tax Bill|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/12/19/us/politics/tax-bill-house-live-vote.html?_r=1|website=The New York Times|access-date=31 December 2017|date=19 December 2017}}</ref> After voting for the act, he called the economy "stunted" and a "burden" on Americans, adding, "The importance of this moment cannot be overstated. With the first comprehensive tax reform in 31 years, we will dramatically strengthen the U.S. economy and restore economic mobility and opportunity for hardworking individuals and families all across this country."<ref name="BPT122017">{{cite web|title=Johnson on tax reform: 'Republicans have fulfilled our promise' - Bossier Press-Tribune|url=http://bossierpress.com/johnson-tax-reform-republicans-fulfilled-promise/|website=bossierpress.com|access-date=31 December 2017}}</ref>

On May 19, 2021, Johnson and all other seven Republican House leaders in the 117th Congress voted against establishing a national commission to investigate the January 6, 2021 [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|storming of the United States Capitol]]. Thirty-five Republican House members and all 217 Democrats present voted to establish such a commission.<ref>[https://clerk.house.gov/Votes/2021154 Roll Call 154 Bill Number: H. R. 3233 117th Congress, 1st Session], ''[[United States House of Representatives]]'', May 19, 2021. Retrieved May 20, 2021.</ref><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/05/19/jan-6-commission-vote/ How Republicans voted on a commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol riot], ''[[Washington Post]]'', May 19, 2021. Retrieved May 20, 2021.</ref>

After the [[2022 United States House of Representatives elections|2022 midterm elections]], representative [[Andy Biggs]] proposed Johnson as a possible compromise candidate for [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] instead of [[House Republican Conference|Republican Conference]] leader [[Kevin McCarthy]].<ref>[https://thehill.com/homenews/house/3763799-biggs-renews-challenge-to-mccarthy-amid-lack-of-consensus-alternative/ Biggs renews challenge to McCarthy amid lack of consensus alternative], ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', December 6, 2022. Retrieved December 14, 2022.</ref>

=== Caucus memberships ===

* [[Freedom Caucus]]<ref>{{Cite news|last=Desiderio|first=Andrew|date=2018-11-28|title=Meet the Double Agent Who Now Controls House Conservatives|language=en|work=The Daily Beast|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/meet-the-double-agent-who-now-controls-house-conservatives|access-date=2021-04-25}}</ref>
*[[Republican Study Committee]]<ref>{{Cite web|date=2017-12-06|title=Membership|url=https://rsc-banks.house.gov/about/membership|access-date=2021-03-28|website=Republican Study Committee|language=en}}</ref>

==Political positions==
[[File:FRC President Tony Perkins presents the "True Blue" award to Congressman Mike Johnson.jpg|thumb|right|Johnson receiving the True Blue award from [[Family Research Council|FRC]] President [[Tony Perkins (politician)|Tony Perkins]] in 2018]]

=== Immigration ===
Johnson supported President [[Donald Trump]]'s 2017 [[Executive Order 13769|executive order]] to prohibit immigration from seven predominantly Muslim countries, saying: "This is not an effort to ban any religion, but rather an effort to adequately protect our homeland. We live in a dangerous world, and this important measure will help us balance freedom and security."<ref name="Blake1">{{cite web|last1=Blake|first1=Aaron|title=Coffman, Gardner join Republicans against President Trump's travel ban; here's where the rest stand|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/01/29/republicans-on-trump-travel-ban/|website=Denver Post|date=29 January 2017|access-date=30 January 2017}}</ref>

=== Abortion ===
Johnson opposes abortion and supports legislation to prohibit abortions after week 20 of a pregnancy.<ref name="KALB10417">{{cite web|title=La. Representatives give their take on abortion|url=http://www.kalb.com/content/news/La-Representatives-give-their-take-on-abortion-449400823.html|website=KALB|publisher=Associated Press|access-date=31 December 2017|language=en}}</ref>

=== Cannabis ===
Johnson believes [[medical marijuana]] is a "[[gateway drug]]" to other drugs.<ref name="LRN51216">{{cite web|title=Medical marijuana bill gets approval from the House|url=http://www.louisianaradionetwork.com/blogs/medical-marijuana-bill-gets-approval-from-the-house#.WkkpUFQ-dE4|website=Louisiana Radio Network|access-date=31 December 2017}}</ref>

=== Donald Trump ===
In 2019, Johnson said, "President Trump cooperated fully with the [Special Counsel Mueller] investigation."<ref>{{Cite news|last=Crisp|first=Elizabeth|date=July 24, 2019|title=Louisiana U.S. Reps. Cedric Richmond, Mike Johnson question special counsel Robert Mueller|website=[[NOLA]]|url=https://www.nola.com/news/politics/article_77f54498-ae2b-11e9-a55b-af94df5eb0df.html|access-date=Dec 19, 2019}}</ref>

Johnson served as a member of Trump's legal defense team during both the 2019 and 2020 Senate impeachment trials, which resulted in acquittals.<ref>Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump</ref>

In December 2020, Johnson was one of 126 Republican members of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] to sign an [[amicus brief]] in support of ''[[Texas v. Pennsylvania]]'', a lawsuit filed at the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] contesting the results of the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]], in which [[Joe Biden]] defeated<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blood|first1=Michael R.|last2=Riccardi|first2=Nicholas|date=December 5, 2020|title=Biden officially secures enough electors to become president|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-elections-electoral-college-3e0b852c3cfadf853b08aecbfc3569fa|url-status=live|access-date=December 12, 2020|website=[[Associated Press|AP News]]|archive-date=December 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208201209/https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-elections-electoral-college-3e0b852c3cfadf853b08aecbfc3569fa}}</ref> incumbent [[Donald Trump]]. The Supreme Court declined to hear the case on the basis that Texas lacked [[Standing (law)|standing]] under [[Article Three of the United States Constitution|Article III of the Constitution]] to challenge the results of an election held by another state.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|author-link=Adam Liptak|date=2020-12-11|title=Supreme Court Rejects Texas Suit Seeking to Subvert Election|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/11/us/politics/supreme-court-election-texas.html|access-date=2020-12-12|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211234955/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/11/us/politics/supreme-court-election-texas.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=Order in Pending Case|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/121120zr_p860.pdf|date=2020-12-11|publisher=[[Supreme Court of the United States]]|access-date=December 11, 2020|archive-date=December 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201211234004/https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/121120zr_p860.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/politics/read-house-republicans-texas-supreme-court/index.html|title=Brief from 126 Republicans supporting Texas lawsuit in Supreme Court|first=Daniella |last=Diaz|work=[[CNN]]|access-date=December 11, 2020|archive-date=December 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201212000435/https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/10/politics/read-house-republicans-texas-supreme-court/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== LGBT rights ===
Johnson opposed the results of ''[[Obergefell vs. Hodges]]'', which legalized same-sex marriage across the US. He believes the decision should be state by state, not made by the Supreme Court.<ref name="Dickerson12616">{{cite web|last1=Dickerson|first1=Seth|title=Mike Johnson: Wants to 'make government work again'|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/2016/12/06/mike-johnson-wants-make-government-work-again/94627944/|website=shreveporttimes.com|access-date=31 December 2017|language=en}}</ref> In 2022, Johnson introduced the [[Stop the Sexualization of Children Act]], replicating [[Florida Parental Rights in Education Act|Florida's Parental Rights in Education Act]], which would prohibit federally funded institutions, including public schools, from promoting or mentioning gender identity. The bill has been compared to the Florida legislation as a "national Don't Say Gay" bill.<ref name=":02">{{Cite news |last=Wamsley |first=Laurel |date=2022-10-21 |title=What's in the so-called Don't Say Gay bill that could impact the whole country |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/10/21/1130297123/national-dont-say-gay-stop-children-sexualization-bill |access-date=2022-10-23}}</ref>

===Government-sponsored school prayer===
In April 2018, Johnson joined Republican state [[Attorney General of Louisiana|Attorney General]] [[Jeff Landry]] and Christian [[actor]] [[Kirk Cameron]] to argue under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] for student-led [[School prayer|prayer]] and religious expression in public schools. Johnson and Landry appeared, with Cameron who spoke on a promotional video, at prayer rallies at the First Baptist Church of [[Minden, Louisiana|Minden]] and Bossier Parish Community College in Bossier City. The gatherings were organized by area pastors, including Brad Jurkovich of First Baptist Bossier, in response to a lawsuit filed in February against the [[Bossier Parish School Board]] and the superintendent, Scott Smith. Smith and the board were accused of permitting teachers to incorporate various aspects of Christianity in their class presentations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/2018/04/06/actor-kirk-cameron-makes-promo-video-bossier-webster-prayer-rallies/486983002/|title=Actor Kirk Cameron makes promo video for Bossier, Webster prayer rallies|newspaper=The Shreveport Times|first=Nick|last=Wooten|date=April 6, 2018|access-date=April 14, 2018}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Johnson is married to the Kelly Lary, a licensed Pastoral Counselor, a lecturer on family-related issues, and a former school teacher. They have four children. Johnson formerly resided in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], and in [[Allen, Texas|Allen]], [[Collin County, Texas|Collin County]], [[Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intelius.com/results.php?ReportType=1&formname=name&qf=Kelly&qmi=M&qn=Lary&qcs=Benton%2C+LA&focusfirst=1|title=James M. Johnson in Benton, Louisiana|publisher=intelius.com|access-date=March 30, 2015}}</ref>
